results.title: La Bijouterie Jacquelin = Jacquelin Jeweller
results.brief_description:
Vicdocq is back in Paris, with poor old Flambart forever on his trail. After a close encounter with the police, Vidocq seeks refuge in a jewellery shop which happens to belong to Jacquelin, an old army pal. Jacquelin immediately hires Vidocq to work in the shop where his past experiences as a convict proves useful to fend off swindlers of all kind. Vidocq also becomes quite taken by Jacquelin’s upstairs neighbour, Annette.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Leonce Corne, Jacques Bodoin.

results.title: La Bible = the Bible
results.brief_description:
This version of the Bible is illustrated by the mosaics of Monreale, near Palermo (Sicily).

Credits: Producer, Andre Tranche ; director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Marcel Carne, Didier Decoin ; photography, Jean Collomb ; music, Jean-Pierre Benjamin.

results.title: La Bete Humaine = the Human Beast
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
“So that the trains and the costumes of another era would not distract his audience, Jean Renoir situated his adaptation of Zola’s novel in 1938. He wanted to make a true tragedy. The hero, Jacques Lantier, is haunted by the curse of alcoholism, and the action from start to finish has a driving intensity that Zola would not have disavowed. Lantier burns with passion for Severine, a strange little creature whose callowness results in a kind of nonchalance bordering on frigidity. She is the accomplice of her jealous husband and passively assists in the murder of her old benefactor and lover. Lantier catches them in the act, and out of love says nothing. He is unable to kill her husband when she asks him to and he ends up strangling her in a fit of passion. Mad with grief, he kills himself, which is not the way Zola ended his novel. Right before his suicide comes one of the most beautiful moments in film, the justly famous Trainmen’s ball”. Reference: Celia Bertin. ‘Jean Renoir: a life in pictures’. London: John Hopkins University Press, 1991. Jean Renoir appears briefly as Cabuche, the poacher. In this film, Renoir perhaps came closest to the dark mood of fatalistic ‘poetic realism’ that characterised the works of Carne and Duvivier in the 1930s. In August 1939, on the eve of WWII, the French Ministry of Information drew up a list of 51 ‘depressing, morbid, immoral and bad for the youths’ films, including ‘La Bete Humaine’. Re-made in the USA by Fritz Lang as ‘Human Desire’ (1954) with Glenn Ford, Gloria Grahame, Edgar Buchanan.

Credits: Producer, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Curt Courant, Claude Renoir ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Eugene Lourie ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; stills photographer, Sam Levin.
Cast: Credits: Jean Gabin, Simone Simon, Fernand Ledoux, Blanchette Brunoy, Julien Carette.

results.title: La Belle Equipe = They Were Five
results.brief_description:
The fortune of five unemployed labourers take a radical turn for the better when they jointly win a 100,000 francs lottery prize. Jean, the self-appointed leader of the bunch, suggests they invest their money in a ‘guinguette’ (country pub cum outdoor entertainment) on the river Marne. Their dreams of instant success are dashed when Gina, Charles’ girlfriend, shows up demanding her portion of the winnings, then plots the destruction of Jean because he rebuffed her. The film was filmed with two endings. At the first release, the tragic ending chosen by Duvivier was a total flop. After 6 weeks, the film was withdrawn and re-released with a happy ending version. A very beautiful film which will be remembered as one of Duvivier’s finest. It is sensitive without sentimentality, original without effort, populist without vulgarity ; it starts with gaiety and we all feel gay. It ends tragically and our hearts rend. Simple people for a simple story, but with an added dimension of deep tragic poetry, for it shows how destiny can change and look like luck at first, then become fatality.” Source: L’Avant-Scene du Cinema, March 1996.

Credits: Producer, Arys Nissotti ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writer, Julien Duvivier, Charles Spaak ; photography, Jules Kruger, Marc Fossard ; music, Maurice Yvain ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Charles Vanel, Raymond Aimos, Charles Dorat, Viviane Romance, Raphael Medina, Fernand Charpin, Raymond Cordy, Charles Granval.

results.title: La Belle Epoque
results.brief_description:
Episode 24 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
What is commonly know as La Belle Epoque covers the years from 1870 to 1914. It is a time of great progress, both intellectual and technical. This episode focuses of the advances in the automotive industry and railways. Other topics include: the colinzation of the African continent, the construction of the Metro in Paris and the cinematograph. The October Revolution in Russia and the beginning of the mobilization in 1914 are also mentionned.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: La Beaute du Diable = Beauty and the Devil
results.brief_description:
Rene Clair became fascinated with a structural defect in the ‘Faust’ legend, wondering what would happen if, instead of forcing Faust to sign his soul away in exchange for happiness and knowledge, the Devil were to ask for nothing, and simply assume that Faust would sign the contract at a later date. Since Hiroshima, the nuclear threat was a constant source of concern, and Clair’s film was released in a Cold War climate in which Faust regains his soul only after rejecting the thought of owning limitless powers.

Credits: Producers, Salvo d’Angelo, Rene Clair ; director, Rene Clair ; writers, Rene Clair, Armand Salacrou ; photography, Michel Kelber ; music, Roman Vlad ; assistant director, Michel Boisrond ; costumes, Mayo.
Cast: Michel Simon, Gerard Philipe, Simone Valere, Nicole Besnard, Carlo Ninchi, Paolo Stoppa, Raymond Cordy, Gaston Modot.

results.title: La Baraque Aux 36 Etoiles = the 36 Stars Fair Booth
results.brief_description:
Annette finally reaches the town of Mezieres and finds a job in a travelling circus. She is preparing an escape plan for Vidocq. The plan involves seducing the prison governor who has installed what he thinks is a failsafe alarm system in the prison: a bell that can be actionned from the corridor.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Bruno Balp, Camiret, Germaine Delbat, Pierre Tornade.

results.title: La Bamba (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Luis Valdez, Taylor Hackford, New Visions Pictures and Columbia
results.brief_description: Musical biography of Ritchie Valens, a poor Mexican-American who became a rock’n’roll sensation at age 17 in the 1950’s. Lou Diamond Phillips portrays Valens whose musical career ended when he was killed in the plane crash that also claimed the life of Buddy Holly. The music of Valens is performed by Los Lobos on the soundtrack.

results.title: La Balance (S)
results.creator_credit: Bob Swaim, Films A2 and Les Film Ariane
results.brief_description: Heightened crime and increased prosititution in the streets of Paris, force the criminal investigation department to set up a special unit of police called the Territorial Brigades. Their only hope of penetrating the French Maffia is through a network of informers but the perfect informer is killed and another must be found from the pimps and prostitutes of the French underground. Voted the best film of the year in France at the time of its release, La Balance is a world of violence where only the tough survive. This version is dubbed in English.
